verses.verse: He left there and came into his hometown, and his disciples followed him.

When the Sabbath had arrived, he began to teach in the synagogue and many hearing were amazed saying, "Where did this man get these things, and what wisdom is given to him that even such mighty works are done through his hands?
"Isn't this the carpenter, the son of Mary, the brother of James, Joseph, Judah, and Simon? Aren't his sisters here with us?" They were offended because of him.
But Jesus said to them, "A prophet is not without honor, except in his home area and among his own relatives and his own family."
He could do no miracle there except he laid his hands on a few sick people and healed them.
He was greatly surprised, because of their unbelief. He went around to the villages teaching.
He called for the twelve and started sending them out two by two and gave them authority over unclean spirits.
He gave orders that they should take nothing for their journey, except for a walking stick, no bag for provisions, no food, no money in a belt,
only shod with sandals, and not to put on two tunics.
He said to them, "Whenever you enter a house, stay there until you leave there,

and whosoever will not welcome you nor listen to you, when you leave there, shake off the dusk under your feet as a testimony against them. Truly I say to you that it will be more tolerable for Sodom and Gomorrah in the Day of Judgment than for that city."
So they went out and preached that men should repent.
They cast out many devils and anointed with oil many who were sick and healed them.
King Herod heard [about him]--for his name had spread around-and he said that John the Baptist had risen from the dead, that's why miracles are at work in him.
Others said that this is Elijah. Others said that it is a prophet or like one of the prophets.
But when Herod heard, he said, "It is John whom I beheaded; he is risen from the dead."
For Herod himself had sent, seized John and bound him in prison for Herodias' sake, his brother Philip's wife, for he had married her.
John had said to Herod, "It is against the Law for you to have your brother's wife."
Therefore Herodias had a grudge against him and would have killed him, but she couldn't,
for Herod feared John knowing that he was a just man and holy, and he kept him safe. When he heard him, he did many things and gladly heard him.
But when a convenient day had come [and] Herod on his birthday made a feast for his lords, high-ranking officers, and foremost citizens of Galilee.
And the daughter of this Herodias came in, danced, and pleased Herod and those who sat with him; the king said to the young woman, "Ask me whatever you want, and I will give it to you."
And he swore an oath to her, "Whatever you will ask, I will give it to you, up to half my kingdom."
She went out and said to her mother, "What should I ask for?" And she said, "The head of John the Baptist."
She came in immediately with haste to the king and asked saying, "I want you to give me as soon as possible on a plate the head of John the Baptist."
The king was grieved, [yet] for his oath's sake and for those who sat there with him, he would not refuse her.
Immediately the king sent an executioner and commanded his head to be brought, and [the executioner] left, beheaded him in the prison,
brought his head on a plate, and gave it to the young woman, and the young woman gave it to her mother.
When his disciples heard [about it], they came and took his dead body and laid it in a tomb.
The apostles gathered together near to Jesus and told him everything, what they had done, and what they had taught.
And he said to them, "You go by yourselves into a solitary place and relax awhile," for many were coming and going, and they had no time to even eat.
Then they left for a solitary place privately by ship.
And the people saw them leaving and many knew him and ran on foot from out of all the cities, outpaced them, and came together to him.
And when Jesus came out, he saw many people and was moved with compassion for them, because they were as sheep without a shepherd. He began to teach them many things.
When the day was nearly over, his disciples came to him and said, "This is an solitary place, and now the hour is getting late.
"Send them away, so that they may go into the surrounding area and into the villages and buy bread for themselves, because they have nothing to eat."
He answered and said to them, "You give them something to eat." They said to him, "Should we go and buy two hundred denarii's worth of bread and give it to them to eat?"
He said to them, "How many loaves do you have? Go and see." And when they knew, they said, "Five plus two fish."
He ordered them to have all sit down in groups on the green grass.
And they sat down like beds in a garden, by hundreds and fifties.
When he had taken the five loaves and two fish, he looked up to heaven, blessed, divided the loaves, and gave to his disciples to set before them, and the two fish he divided among them all.
They all ate and were filled.
Then they took up twelve baskets full of leftover bread and fish.
Those who ate from the loaves were about five thousand men.
Immediately he made his disciples get into the ship and go to the other side towards Bethsaida, while he sent the people away.
When he had sent them away, he went to a mountain to pray.
And when evening had come, the ship was in the midst of the sea, but he was alone on the land.
And he saw them struggling in rowing, for the wind was against them. Around the fourth watch of the night, he came to them, walking on the sea and would have passed them,
but when they saw him walking on the sea, they thought they saw a ghost and screamed.
For they all saw him and were afraid. Immediately he talked to them and said to them, "Cheer up; it is I; don't be afraid."
He climbed up to them into the ship; the wind stopped, and in themselves they were absolutely stunned beyond measure and marveled.
For they didn't remember the [miracle] of the loaves, for their heart was calloused.
Having passed over, they came to the region of Gennesaret and landed.
When they had come out of the ship, they immediately recognized him,
and ran through the whole region and started to carry those who were sick on mats to where they heard he was.

And whenever he entered villages, cities, or country, they laid the sick in the streets and begged him, in order that they might touch only the edge of his clothes, and as many as touched him were made well.
